results.t: What is DHCP? and Why is it important? - EfficientIP

results.p: Jul 29, 2021 — DHCP is a client/server protocol that automatically provides an Internet Protocol (IP) host with its IP address and other related configuration information.

results.t: What is DHCP? and Why is it important?
results.p: What is DHCP? DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) is a network protocol used to automate the process of configuring devices on networks.

results.t: What is DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol)?
results.p: It's the standard mechanism to dynamically assign IP addresses within a network. It stands for Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol.

results.t: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol - an overview
results.p: The Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is used to automatically (or dynamically) assign IP addresses to host computers on a network running TCP/IP.

results.t: What is DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol)
results.p: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is a network protocol used to automatically assign IP addresses to all devices on your network. Learn more!
